title: Are humans the most important species on the planet? - Quora

response.answer_text: Who is supposed to assign “importance” to things, you mean? “Important” is a relative term, it requires that you specify some criteria by which to judge it. The human population makes up effectively 0% of the total population of living things on Earth, as nearly everything is bacteria. There are 7 billion humans, which may sound like a lot, but there are something like 10^30 bacteria, which makes non-bacteria some very, very tiny fraction of a percent of the life of Earth. So, effectively zero. Humans surely have the most impact on the Earth, in terms of changing the environment, at least in very recent history. But humans have existed for only about 2.5 million years, while life has existed for around 4 billion years, so humans haven’t been around for more than a moment, and we haven’t had an impact on the Earth for more than a tiny moment. In the future, we’ll defnitely continue affecting the world like no other species currently does, and like no other species ever has. Currently, we are the greatest disaster ever known to life on Earth, as we’re killing life faster than any disaster ever has, including what we call “the great dying”, which was otherwise the largest catastrophe that life has ever seen. We are killing things faster than that, because of how we’re changing the Earth. So we will absolutely be an important factor for how the world will change in the future, but we also cannot forget that we’re newcomers, and that bacteria still remain the dominant force on Earth, as they basically always have been, and that we live by their mercy (metaphorically), still.

Important in what sense? To the environment? Not exactly. To the welfare of domesticated animals and plants? I suppose, although that I don't know that humans aren't doing more harm than good with our current level of meddling with things we don't understand.  I don't know if we're that important, but I'd certainly say that we're that selfish. Self preservation is the highest law for any species, although there are many examples of people martyring themselves, I don't think it will ever become the norm.

My instincts are to say no. The march of science and discovery has been a fairly consistent reduction of our sense of importance. We’re not at the center of the universe. We’re not the product of a special creation event. We’re not that different from the other animals, we’re not as good and perceiving and understanding the world around us as we thought… But I’m going to say yes. We’re having a huge impact on the planet. We’re changing the climate. We currently move more rock and soil around than all the natural processes combined. While we haven’t created new species yet, we will soon, and we’ve certainly altered some beyond recognition. There is an extinction event underway, and we’re at the center of it. I think that makes us pretty important, but not in a good way. More in the way that the Plague was important to European history.

No. Importance is a subjective and relative term, not an objective one. Most humans believe (either because of religion and/or other reasons) that they are the “most important” species on the planet due to whatever lies they’ve been told throughout their lives. Objectively and as far as the rest of nature goes however, human life is no more or less important or “special” than that of bacterial life, and/or the lives of all other past, present, and future species. My 2 cents.

Importance is massively relative notion. One thing does not have import in and of itself - it has importance with respect to something else. If you’re going to ask this kind of question, you need to specify exactly in what sense a species on this planet might qualify as more or less important than another - and in doing so you will probably end up answering your own question.
Important to whom? To ourselves? Sure! To mealworms or dolphins? Not so much. Like many things, it’s all about context.

This is a hard question that brings up the ethical question of what makes humans more valuable than other species? There is really no way to measure how valuable a species is. However, from our perspective humans are most important. From a lion’s perspective, lions are the most important. IMO. Humans are the most important species on the planet. I can’t say they aren’t because if all humans were to die right now, then that’d affect me a lot. It’s up to who/what is being asked. For all humans, the logical answer should be that humans are the most important species.
No, the most important species is the one that will evolve to replace humans and become the dominant species on Earth.
No. Everything alive is environmentally interconnected. If living things become reduced in numbers or extinct, the rest of the living things will suffer in their own existence sooner or later.
The planet isa dead piece of rock. Nothing is important to it. We are however, the most advanced.
I wouldn’t say the most important but definitely the most destructive.
No. COWS are. With out cows we could not FEED 8 billion people.
